title.rendered: Houses flooded as Russian Missiles hit a Ukrainian Dam

content.rendered:
Oleksandr Vilkul, the municipal manager, stated that residents in some districts had been instructed to leave but stressed that the issue was under control.

Russia allegedly carried out the bombing in retribution for Ukraine’s recent offensive.

After the attack on the Karachunivske reservoir, the city-born president Volodymyr Zelensky referred to Russia as a “terrorist state.”

In his late-night speech on Wednesday, Mr. Zelensky referred to you as “weaklings who fight people.” Criminals have fled the battlefield and are now attempting to cause harm from a great distance.

This appeared to reference Ukraine’s recent military victories in a quick counteroffensive in the nation’s Kharkiv region in the country’s northeast. Russian troops have been forced to retreat due to the Ukrainian army reclaiming large areas of captured land.

In his speech, Mr. Zelensky claimed that the reservoir had “essentially no military value.”

According to Mr. Vilkul, two blasts were made overnight to boost the water flow from the dam to the Inhulets river.

The onslaught in the city, which had pre-war inhabitants of more than 600,000, impacted the city’s water sources.

According to officials, water breached the river’s banks after the dam failed and flooded some homes.

On Thursday morning, Mr. Vilkul stated that the Inhulets River’s water levels had “much decreased” by this point. There were none, he claimed.

Regarding the alleged missile strikes, Moscow has not made any public remarks.

The Russian military had previously acknowledged targeting energy-producing sites that resulted in extensive blackouts last weekend that affected millions of residents in eastern Ukraine.

On Wednesday, Mr. Zelensky traveled to Izyum, a significant logistics hub in the Kharkiv region and a recently regained city.

He expressed gratitude to the soldiers who took part in the counteroffensive and promised to restore the Ukrainian flag to every town and city in the nation.

According to accounts, several Russian personnel abandoned their uniforms to blend in with the civilian population in response to the speed of the Ukrainian assault.

Russia has acknowledged that some of the towns in the Kharkiv region have been abandoned by its troops but has refrained from using the term “retreat,” saying that its troops are instead reorganizing. Even in Russia itself, this assertion was widely mocked in the West.

War crimes charges against Russia have begun to surface as Kyiv’s forces advance into the previously seized territory.

Residents of Balakliya, a town in the Kharkiv region, told the BBC that soldiers had tortured residents at the police station during the Russian occupation. Other locals described being electrocuted while being held captive.

Russia has vehemently denied committing civilian targets.

Moscow asserted that it was now focusing on the Donbas after failing in March to take Ukraine’s cities, as well as the capital Kyiv, in the north and north-east, some of which were already held by rebels supported by Russia before the Russian invasion.

Russian officials have stated that they will continue their invasion “until all the initial goals are realized.”

Although army advances have been slower, a separate Ukrainian counterattack is still ongoing in the southern Kherson region.
